turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Well -- I -- I-

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Don't be cross with him, Ma. This don't happen every day.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Potato bug sits on the leaf in the sun, Sleep, sleep, my baby -- Raccoon sits in the spruce all night, Sleep, baby, sleep --

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: What in sugar hill's the matter with him?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Nothing, Jabez -- just natural for a baby to cry, sometimes.  Shh, little Daniel -- sleep -- sleep --

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: What happened.... Where are you taking him?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I am going to lock him up.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: You're not supposed to punish my son, Mary.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Jabez -- how can you let her talk like that when the boy is present? He won't respect me any more.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Isn't that your own fault?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: My fault? ... Oh, Jabez -- all I want is to be proud of him. He can be such a fine boy, if we show him how to be.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: He's my son and I like him the way he is. Why do you always have to pick on him? If it's not the boy it's me. You don't like the way I live -- you don't like my friends, or my new house -- or anything.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: But Jabez, I never said that!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: It shows on your face.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Well -- I am worried about the way you've changed. That was one thing you said you'd never do -- remember?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Oh, for heaven's sake, leave me alone!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Why don't they come --

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I don't know, Jabez.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Think this room is larger than anything Webster's got at Marshfield? You've been there. What about it, Mary?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It's -- different, Jabez -- that's all.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: What's the matter with 'em? Why don't they come?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Mr. Webster ... Wait! ...  Mary!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Jabez!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Mary! Come back ...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh, Jabez! ...  Did you hear, Mr. Webster? --  Now you'll help him, won't you?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: You must go now, Mary -- you must!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: All right, Jabez ...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Jabez -- Jabez!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Mary!

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: "There was a man in the land of Uz whose name was Job; and that man was perfect and upright, and one that feared God and eschewed evil."

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Consarn the consarn --

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Jabez! What kind of talk is that for the Sabbath? And me a-reading the holy word!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Sorry, Ma -- but this consar-- this little pig --  He won't let me fix him --

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: You know that, son.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Hard luck -- like me.

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Now, Jabez Stone -- as for what you're calling hard luck -- well, we made New England out of it. That and codfish.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: That's right, Ma -- we ain't licked yet. A Stone's never licked till he's dead -- that's what Dad used to say, didn't he, Ma?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: There! Guess that ought to hold good. Put him down here, by the fire, Mary.  But we don't want to get him too close -- we'll have roast pork for supper.

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Not on the Sabbath you won't, Jabez!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: How'd you know to have the calf ready, Ma?

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: I just figgered -- knew you didn't have enough bills.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Yes -- and you figgered right, consarn it!

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: That's a word you're too free with lately, Jabez, consarn this and consarn that ...

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Helps sometimes to say it.

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: All right, son -- if it helps.

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: What's ailing that dog?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: I dunno.

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Well ... make him keep quiet.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: And why should I? Let him howl if it makes him feel good.  Consarn it. He's better off than I am! I wish I could tell Him...  ... up there, just what I think.

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Hush up such talk, Jabez!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: I can't help it. I mean it, I tell you. I've had more than my share. Nothing ever goes right for me -- nothing!

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: You found it in the barn, hey?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Yes -- I was getting the seed -- I stumbled -- I saw one of the boards warped up a bit -- and -- there it was.

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Most outlandish thing I ever heard tell.  Don't seem right, somehow!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: But it's true. Take 'em up in your hands, Mary -- feel 'em -- they're real all right.  Aren't you glad?

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Well -- that's comforting!  Supper.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Say, Mary, how is your shoulder?

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Well, son, I'm glad to see a Stone come up in the world again.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Now look here, Ma. I'm not a boy anymore. I want that understood. I don't aim to stay a one-horse farmer the rest of my life. Mary's got to be the kind of wife a -- a big man needs --

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: It won't be the first baby ever born in this house.  There! Made me drop a stitch!  Sit down, you make me nervous!  Lan's, that's the way a man always is. Thinks his son's the most important thing in the world.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: My son! Do you really think, Ma....

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Oh, go along with you! As if it mattered to a grandma! But p'raps you got an even chance.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Queer sort of weather we're having -- queer like everything else.

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Well, thank the Lord you can always depend on New England for weather. We've got enough for the whole United States.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: I feel -- fidgety, Ma -- not right at all.

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Lan's, I'd think you was having the baby, to hear you.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Me -- a son.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Money -- money's a funny thing, ain't it, Ma?

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: I figure that depends a mite on how you get it and how you spend it, Son.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Do you really think that?

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Why, that's just sense, Son. Now a man like Daniel Webster -- guess they pay him high for what he does. But he's worth it -- and he helps others. Makes all the difference.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: I know, Ma, but -- Suppose a man got his money in bad ways --

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Wouldn't profit him none.

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: You see, son? I'm old and I've lived. When a man gets his money in bad ways -- when he sees the better course and takes the worse -- then the devil is in his heart -- and that fixes him.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Ma -- and yet, a man could change that, couldn't he?

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: A man can always change things, Son. That's what makes him different from barnyard critters.

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Oh, here you are, Jabez. Lan's, I was worried about you.... Hail in August! The crops will be ruined!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: It don't matter!

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: What's that you say, Son?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: I say -- it don't matter.

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Now that's the way to talk, Son! I know you worked hard for that crop. But we'll make out.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Make out? We'll do better than that!  I never thought I'd be glad for bad luck, but I am. I never thought I'd be glad of a hail storm at harvest time, but I am! Oh, bless ye the works of the Lord in the hail and the storm and the rain!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Ma -- is she? --

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: You'll be a father any minute now.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Golly, Ma --  Consarn that music! Shouldn't a-had the harvest festival tonight.

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Fiddlesticks! She don't hear it. Got better music to listen to than that.  There -- that's what I mean.

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: You go down and see what's keeping Dorothy.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Sure, Ma.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: I want you to fix these fish!

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: And I say she won't! I'll not have the scorn of God on this place -- with the smell of fish in it, polluting up the Sabbath!  And as for you -- let me tell you, young woman...!

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: My son ... what's the matter?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Ma! ...  Where's Mary ... and little Dan'l?

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Gone with Daniel Webster -- to Marshfield, son.... You told Mary to go--

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Ma -- Ma -- it's all right, Ma!

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Of course it's all right, son. You had Daniel Webster, didn't ye?  Breakfast's ready!  I've made a special surprise for Mr. Webster.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Yep -- you can't get around that mortgage. -- I'm sorry, Jabez.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: It's all right, Sheriff.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Wish I could really do something for you. But you know Stevens. He'll throw you off your farm tomorrow if you don't pay him tonight.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Let him try it.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: The law is the law. Good-bye, Mary.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Hello, Sheriff.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Hello, Jabez -- I was just talking to Stevens about a little extension on your payment.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: And you didn't get it, hey? Come on, we'll have another talk with him.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: It seems such an obvious candidature to us all.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Very well, folks. I accept.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Come in, Sheriff.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Jabez -- seems  like I've been hearing talk around. Reverend Harper thinks more Cross Corners folk oughter be in church, Sabbath morning.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Belle, give the Sheriff a cup of rum.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You throw mighty far, Jabez -- almost into the pigsty.

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Mary -- Jabez --

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Coming, Ma.

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Well, I guess we won't be going to church today.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I guess we won't.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: That is -- if you don't mind changing the lesson, Ma.

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Land sakes, I don't mind. I never did hold much with Job, even if he is Scripture. He took on too much to suit me. I don't want to malign the man, but he always sounded to me as if he came from Massachusetts. Yes, Mary, you go ahead and read.

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Let her be, son. She'll do all right. You better get yourself straightened out.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yes, Jabez -- don't worry.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'll try hard -- I just can't take it all in.

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: H'm. Hessian gold. Well -- hope it'll do us more good than it did the Hessians.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You know, Ma, why the Squire came to see Jabez?

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Yes, Mrs. Slossum told me -- Lucy can't even keep a secret -- Selectman -- my son -- well, who would have thought of that?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What a nice -- and kind girl --  Who is she --?

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: The new girl -- Jabez says; she is from over the mountain.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What mountain?

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Mary! Ready? First bell's a-ringing!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yes, Ma -- I'm ready --

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: She'll do nothing of the kind! She's going to church with me, right away!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Jabez -- for the good of your soul ... please come with us.

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Fox hunting -- a Stone going fox hunting on a week day -- and the earth crying out for the touch of him!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Now, Ma -- You just try to set an example for me, and keep hold of yourself.

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Me? Why, look here, Mary Stone -- I'm worried about you, that's all.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Worried about me! Well, you just stop it!

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I said you should stop worrying because I've made up my mind!

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: So you've made up your mind to go to the party.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You aren't angry with me?

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Ah, fiddlesticks -- you are old enough to know what you are doing.

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Be sure to let me know if Daniel is over there.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I won't forget.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: What are you looking for, Colonel?  What's your name?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Martin Van Buren Aldrich and my Pa's the only Democrat in Cross Corners. He said you had horns and a tall, Mr. Webster, but I ain't seen 'em yet.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Well, Martin, I only wear them in Washington -- that's the trouble. But if you ever come down there, I'll show them to you.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Gee, would you, Mr. Webster? Honest?

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Of course. And you tell your father for me -- we may be on opposite sides of the fence, but I'm always glad to hear of a man who holds to his own opinions. As long as people do that -- the country's all right. Do you understand, Martin?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Yes, sir -- I guess I do -- Gee --

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It is.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: You've got a smart man, Mrs. Stone. Hang onto him.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: -- I'm going to try, Mr. Webster.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Well Mary, it's too bad I didn't know -- I would have given you a real dinner, but with my wife being in Washington -- Have another piece of pie --

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No, really, thank you. -- Is Mrs. Webster coming back soon?

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Well -- she hardly ever comes here -- she's not the type of woman who cares to live in the country. Yes -- I'm all on my own -- sometimes it makes you feel a little lonely --  Do you mind if I indulge?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Of course not --

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: No, you wouldn't -- You're not the sort of woman that's afraid of smoke -- or fire -- But now let's talk about your affairs.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Goodness, Mr. Webster, I've done nothing but talk about that all through dinner.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Yes, you've chatted a lot, woman-like nibbling around the edge -- But, Mary, forgive an old lawyer's legal mind, I don't think you ever once came to the point. And there is a point, isn't there?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Why -- yes -- it's hard to put it into words, Mr. Webster. There's this matter of little Daniel's schooling and the new house -- and well -- there's something else that's wrong -- it gets worse, year after year -- it's like a shadow growing -- I can't really talk about it, even to Ma -- she puts it all on Jabez and I won't stand for that.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: I've heard some odd things about Jabez lately -- he seems to make the wrong kind of name for himself.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Mr. Webster, you mustn't believe all that people say.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: You don't have to defend him to me, Mary -- I've been called names myself.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You see, I don't care if we are rich or poor -- I don't care if we're big or small, all I care about is Jabez. He was the first man I loved. He never used to care about money -- we were poor as Job's turkey, but none of us minded. Now I've seen him drive the poor from the door, and we used to be poor ourselves. I've seen him get hard and mean, and he isn't hard or mean. I've heard him mock at the church bells -- the bells that rang for our wedding. That's not like him, Mr. Webster -- It must be my fault somehow -- my fault.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Mary -- you've talked to me as you might have talked to your father and I believe he wants me to help you a little. You see, sometimes we think we're licked in this life -- but we weren't put here to be licked. Don't you believe it. Sometimes the shadows seem to get hold of us -- the shadows and the evil -- but it is still up to us to fight. Now I was thinking before you came, of coming over to Cross Corners end of the month, to get acquainted with my Godson -- and other things.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh, could you, Mr. Webster ?

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: And now come on, Mary. I want to show you the all-fired biggest parsnips in the whole United States, raised right here in Marshfield -- of course!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh -- Mr. Webster -- I'm so glad you came!

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Are you, Mary?  Well, I guess I'm glad myself -- seeing as how you feel this way.  Party seems to be quite a success.  Lots of guests, anyhow.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Jabez ...

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Mary -- what love and trust could do for your husband, you've done. And frankly, in a very few moments, this is going to be no place for a lady.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Mr. Webster -- you will help him?

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: I'll do my best, Mary.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: There is nothing like a good old country breakfast. Where's Ma?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: She'll be here in a moment. She has a special surprise for you.

turns.speaker: OLD FARMHAND'S VOICE
turns.text: Hey there, Dan'l! Black Dan'l!

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Hullooo!

turns.speaker: OLD FARMHAND'S VOICE
turns.text: Someone to see you, Dan'l!

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: If it's the British Minister, take him around to the pantry and give him some Madeira --

turns.speaker: OLD FARMHAND'S VOICE
turns.text: Just someone from New Hampshire!

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Why, that's different!  Well, boys, I guess we'll knock off. I've got to see a friend.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: It's only a short drive, Mr. Webster.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Oh -- it's you again. What do you want?

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: With the presidential election coming up, I thought I could be of some help, sir.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: I'd rather see you on the side of the opposition.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: I'll be there, too!

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Say, that's pretty good, young man.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Pretty good -- that's perfect!

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Mr. Webster, I presume?

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Attorney of record for Jabez Stone. Might I ask your name?

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Scratch will do for the evening. May I -- join you?

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Why, certainly -- but be careful, Mr. Scratch -- Medford rum has an uncanny habit of kicking back, even with old-timers like yourself.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: It even kicked back -- once at you, didn't it?

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Me?

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Oh ..  not that you ever get drunk! No, indeed! But a kind of overpowering lassitude or, more plainly, a deep and enveloping sleep.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: There isn't enough Medford rum in the whole of New Hampshire to make me sleepy.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Talk has never proved that question, Mr. Webster!  Cup for cup -- what do you say?

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Cup for cup!

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Your spirited efforts on behalf of your clients do you credit, Mr. Webster -- If you have no more arguments to adduce I'll take him along now.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Not so fast, Mr. Scratch. Produce your evidence -- if you have it.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: There, Mr. Webster.  All open and above-board and in due and legal form.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: H'm. This appears -- I say appears -- to be properly drawn. But you shall not have this man! A man isn't property! Mr. Stone is an American citizen, and no American citizen may be forced into the service of a foreign prince.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Foreign? And who calls me a foreigner?

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Well, I never heard the dev-- of your claiming American citizenship.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: And who with better right? When the first wrong was done to the first Indian, I was there. When the first slaver put out for the Congo, I stood on the deck. Am I not spoken of, still, in every church in New England? 'Tis true, the North claims me for a Southerner, and the South for a Northerner, but I am neither. To tell the truth, Mr. Webster, though I don't like to boast of it, my name is older in the country than yours.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Then I stand on the Constitution! I demand a trial for my client.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: You mean -- a jury trial?

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: I do! If I can't win this case with a jury, you shall have me, too. If two New Hampshire men aren't a match for the devil, we'd better give this country back to the Indians.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Very well. -- You shall have your trial, Mr. Webster. The case is hardly one for an ordinary jury --

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Let it be the quick or the dead -- So it is an American judge and an American jury!

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: The quick or the dead! You have said it.  May -- the best man win, Mr. Webster!

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: I'll drink to that, Mr. Scratch!

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Your Honor -- gentlemen of the jury -- this case need not detain us long. It concerns one thing alone -- the transference, barter and sale of a certain piece of property, to wit, his soul by Jabez Stone. That transference, barter or sale is attested by a deed. I offer that deed in evidence and mark it Exhibit A.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: I object.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: My congratulations -- as between two gentlemen.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Why, you long-barreled, slab-sided, lantern- jawed, note-shaving crook, be off with you ...

turns.speaker: STEVENS
turns.text: I wanted to give it all to the church.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: My money? Why, Mister Stevens? What a quaint idea. Come over to the door. I want to speak to you privately. Stop throwing away that money. We mustn't let people see any softness in you, Mister Stevens.... People take advantage of softness, you know. Come out of there -- I'll give you an extension if you'll forget this stupid repentance idea.

turns.speaker: STEVENS
turns.text: That isn't it. It's ... the loneliness, Mr. Scratch ... the loneliness!

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: The loneliness? Lonely with all your gold, Mister Stevens? That hardly makes sense.

turns.speaker: STEVENS
turns.text: I want someone to talk to ...

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: You can talk to me ...

turns.speaker: STEVENS
turns.text: No, no ...  I want to talk to men ... to people in Cross Corners ...to my neighbors ...

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Why don't you?

turns.speaker: STEVENS
turns.text: I can't be honest with them.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Oh, that's what you want -- well, you can be perfectly honest with Jabez Stone -- now.

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: I'm John McClane.

turns.speaker: ARGYLE
turns.text: Argyle.  I'm your limo driver.  Hey, nice bag.

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: Argyle.  Don't you take this stuff?

turns.speaker: ARGYLE
turns.text: Do I?  I'm sorry.  You're gonna have to help me, man.  This is my first time driving a limo.

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: That's okay.  This is my first time riding in one.

turns.speaker: ARGYLE
turns.text: If your friend is hot to trot...I know a couple of mama bears.  ...Or is he married?

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: Married.

turns.speaker: ARGYLE
turns.text: The girl was off today.  Hey, I didn't expect you to sit up front.  So, your lady live out here?

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: The past six months.

turns.speaker: ARGYLE
turns.text: Meanwhile, you still live in New York?

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: You're nosey, you know that, Argyle?

turns.speaker: ARGYLE
turns.text: Hey, I'm sorry.  When I was a cabdriver, see, people expected a little chit chat, a little eccentricity and comaraderie, I forgot how stuck up you limo guys were, so excuse me.

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: It's okay, it's okay.

turns.speaker: ARGYLE
turns.text: So, you divorced of what?

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: She had a good job, it turned into a great career.

turns.speaker: ARGYLE
turns.text: But meant her moving here.

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: Closer to Japan.  You're fast.

turns.speaker: ARGYLE
turns.text: So, why didn't you come?

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: 'Cause I'm a New York cop who used to be a New York kid, and I got six months backlog of New York scumbags I'm still trying to put behind bars. I don't just get up and move.

turns.speaker: ARGYLE
turns.text: You mean you thought she wouldn't make it out here and she'd come crawling on back, so why bother to pack?

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: Like I said, Argyle...you're fast.

turns.speaker: ARGYLE
turns.text: Mind if I play some tunes?

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: How 'bout some Christmas music?

turns.speaker: ARGYLE
turns.text: That is Christmas music.

turns.speaker: ARGYLE
turns.text: So, you go on upstairs to the party, your lady sees you, you run into each other's arms.  Music comes up, you live happily ever after, that it?

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: It's corny, but I could live with it.

turns.speaker: ARGYLE
turns.text: What is it don't work out that way? Where you gonna stay?

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: I'll find someplace.

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: You're all right, Argyle.

turns.speaker: ARGYLE
turns.text: Just remember that when you sign for the tip.  They're paying for it, so don't be shy.

turns.speaker: BIG JOHNSON
turns.text: I'm Special Agent Johnson of the FBI. This is Agent Johnson...no relation.

turns.speaker: ROBINSON
turns.text: Dwayne Robinson, LAPD.  I'm in charge here.

turns.speaker: BIG JOHNSON
turns.text: Not any more.

turns.speaker: BIG JOHNSON
turns.text: One of yours?

turns.speaker: ROBINSON
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: BIG JOHNSON
turns.text: If he's not a terrorist, and he's not a hostage...he's just not part of the equation.

turns.speaker: ROBINSON
turns.text: -- ten blocks?  Are you crazy?  It's Christmas Eve, thousands of people -- the Mayor'll scream bloody murder --

turns.speaker: BIG JOHNSON
turns.text: We must shut down the building.  Go wider --!

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: What's happening?

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: They don't look happy...something's gone wrong.

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: The police...?

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: John.

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: John?  Christ, he could fuck this whole thing up...what does he think he's doing?

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: How about his job?

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: His 'job' is 3000 miles away.  Without him, they might let us go...at least we have a chance...

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Tell that to Mr. Takagi.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Where are you going?

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: I'm tired of sitting here waiting to see who gets us killed first... them...or your husband.  Hi there.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: What are you going to do?

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: Hey, I negotiate million dollar deals for breakfast.  I can handle these clowns.  I want to talk to Hans.  Hans! Sprickenzie talk?

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: John, they're giving me a few minutes to try and talk some sense into you. I know you think you're doing your job, and I can appreciate that, but you're just dragging this thing out. None of us gets out of here until these people can negotiate with the LA police, and they're just not gonna start doing that until you stop messing up the works.

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: Ellis, what have you told them?

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: I told them we're old friends and you were my guest at the party.

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: Ellis...you shouldn't be doing this...

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: Tell me about it.

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: John, I think you could get with the program a little.  The police are here now.  It's their problem. Tell these guys where the detonators are so no one else gets hurt.  Hey, I'm putting my life on the line for you buddy...

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: Don't you think I know that!  Put Hans on!  Hans, listen to me, that shithead doesn't know what kind of scum you are, but I do --

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: What am I, a method actor?  Hans, babe, put away the gun.  This is radio, not television...

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: That asshole's not my friend! I barely know him!  I hate his fucking guts --  -- Ellis, for Christ's sake, tell him you don't mean shit to me --

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: John, how can you say that, after all these years--?  John?  John?

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: Hope I'm not interrupting...?

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: What does he want?

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: You're very perceptive.

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: Hey, I read the papers, I watch 60 minutes, I say to myself, these guys are professionals, they're motivated, they're happening. They want something.  Now, personally, I don't care about your politics. Maybe you're pissed at the Camel Jockeys, maybe it's the Hebes, Northern Ireland, that's none of my business.  I figure, You're here to negotiate, am I right?

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: You're amazing.  You figured this all out already?

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: Hey, business is business.  You use a gun, I use a fountain pen, what's the difference?  To put it in my terms, you're here on a hostile takeover and you grab us for some greenmail but you didn't expect a poison pill was gonna be running around the building.  Hans, baby...I'm your white knight.

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: I must have missed 60 Minutes.  What are you saying?

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: The guy upstairs who's fucking things up?  I can give him to you.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Nothing...

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: See to Heinrich...  Now...you can break the code key...?

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: I know what you are feeling.  But this is not productive --

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: He was my only brother...my only family!  I want blood for my blood.  We search...now.

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: No.  Heinrich's team must finish planting the detonators...and Theo needs time on the vault.  After the			* police come they'll waste hours trying to negotiate...that's when we search			* for this man.  Until then...we do not alter the plan.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: And if he alters it...?						*

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Hans, he killed by brother --

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: Karl, I know you want him, but the police are probably on their way. Maybe we can convince them it was all a mistake, but not if they hear gunshots! If you lock him in he'll be neutralized -- now do it!  Karl?  Karl!

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: He wasn't lying about Marco:  He's thirty stories down on the street. The other man is Heinrich, and I found his body upstairs.  And his bag is missing.

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: He had the detonators!  Theo?  Theo!

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: -- you wouldn't let me kill him when I had the chance --

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: If you'd listened to me he would be neutralized already!

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I don't want neutral...I want dead --

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: 'Asian Dawn Movement?'

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: I read about them in Time magazine.  When these Revolutionary Brothers and Sisters are Free, the hostages in this building will be taken to the roof and they will accompany us in helicopters to the Los Angeles International Airport where you will be given further instructions.  You have two hours to comply.

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: It's beautiful.  I always enjoyed models as a boy.  The exactness, the attention to every foreseeable detail... perfection.

turns.speaker: TAKAGI
turns.text: This is what this is about?  Out building project in Indonesia? Contrary to what you people think, we're going to develop that region... not 'exploit' it.

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: Yes...I know about them.  The code key is a necessary step in accessing the vault.

turns.speaker: TAKAGI
turns.text: You want...money?  What kind of terrorists are you?

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: Who said we were terrorists?

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: The code key, please...?

turns.speaker: TAKAGI
turns.text: It's useless to you!  There's seven safeguards on our vault, and the code key is only one of them!  You'll never get it open!

turns.speaker: TAKAGI
turns.text: I don't know it!  get on a Goddamn jet to Tokyo and ask the chairman! I'm telling you!  You're just going to have to kill me --

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: Bad for your health anyway.

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: Who are you, then?

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: Just the fly in the ointment, Hans. The monkey in the wrench, the pain in the ass -

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: Mr. Mystery Guest.  Are you still there?

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: I wouldn't think of leaving, Hans. Unless you want to open the front door...?

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: I'm afraid not.  But you have me at a loss -- you know my name, but who are you?  Just another American who saw too many movies as a child.  Another orphan of a bankrupt culture who thinks he's John Wayne...Rambo... Marshal Dillion.

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: Actually, I was always partial to Roy Rogers.  I really dug those sequined shirts.

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: Do you really think you have a chance against us, Mr. Cowboy?

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: Hear that?  Talk to me, where are my detonators.  Where are they or shall I shoot another one?  Sooner or later...  ...I might get to someone you do care about.

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: Go fuck yourself.

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: --ohGodplease -- don't kill me -- don't kill me -- you're one of them, I know it --

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: Whoa, whoa, easy man.  I won't hurt you.  Who are you?  What are you looking for?

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: You...you're an American?

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: Only if New Jersey counts.

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: You...you don't work for Nakatomi... and if you're not one of them...

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: I'm a cop from New York.

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: New York...

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: They invited me to the Xmas party. Who knew?

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: Better than being caught with your pants down, right?  John McClane.

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: William Clay.  Call me Bill.

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: Bill, you know how to use a handgun?

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: One weekend I went to a combat ranch...  You know, that game with the, the guns that shoot red paint?  Must sound pretty silly to you...

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: Sounds better than nothing.

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: Hans.  Your Hans.

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: Put it down now.

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: That was tricky, with the accent. I bet you do a great Ed Sullivan. Why do you need the detonators, Hans? I already used the explosives.

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: I'm going to count to three...

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: Yeah.  Like you did with Takagi.

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: Nein, dies ein ist mein.  This time John Wayne does not walk off into the sunset with Grace Kelly.

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: That was Gary Cooper, shithead...

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: No more jokes, drop it or she gets it between the eyes!

turns.speaker: MCCLANE
turns.text: Whoa, Hans, now you're the cowboy?

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: 'Yippe-ki-yea, mother fucker'?  Now you are fucked.

turns.speaker: HANS
turns.text: Then there's no reason not to tell it to us.

turns.speaker: THEO
turns.text: I told you...
